awd_titl_txt: Enhancing Weather and Climate  Learning with Fluid Earth Viewer (FEVer)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Fluid Earth Viewer (FEVer), an interactive and visually appealing web application that will allow users to visualize current and past conditions of our planet's atmosphere and oceans will be built via this award. This free web application, available to anyone with an internet connection, will directly impact approximately 2,000 individuals in-person through three field tests and is expected to reach many more online. 

FEVer will be an extension of an existing open-source web application, and the PIs will add polar data sets, extended options in the user interface, and the ability to view historical climate/weather data to the existing "earth" app. It will be a vehicle of modern Earth science communication, making information most often used by the scientific community accessible and engaging to broader communities. In particular, it will provide hands-on visualization of the important climatic role of the polar-regions, their connections to lower latitudes, and the changes they are undergoing. A companion website, FEVer-Ed, will provide background, educational support, and opportunities for additional learning through a gallery of historically interesting atmospheric and oceanic events. FEVer will serve as a gateway to data sets that have otherwise been inaccessible to audiences outside of the research community. While a number of large data sets are included in this proposal (regional and global operational weather models/reanalyses), the platform is scalable to include other data such as ice sheet and glacier dynamics.

This project is partially funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.

por.por_cntn:
Fluid Earth is an interactive, intuitive, and visually appealing web application that allows users to explore current and past conditions of our planet's atmosphere, oceans, and cryosphere. Fluid Earth, built around a digital globe, is a tool for modern Earth science communication and education, bringing information most often utilized by the scientific community and making it accessible and engaging to everyone. 

User testing with youth, families, and the public allowed the interface to be designed for intuitive navigation and ease of use. Code was optimized to run efficiently on computers, tablets, and smartphones, avoiding bottlenecks in low-bandwidth circumstances and extensive load times on devices. Additional feedback from professional educators allowed features to be included, such as the ability to conduct searches and pin locations, that help with classroom applications. Research Experience for Undergraduates students enhanced the color gradients within Fluid Earth, including altering the palettes for users who have red-green color blindness, and rebuilt the code, following modern design standards for maintenance and expansion, from 2020 to 2022.  

Fluid Earth includes weather and climate data as well as data for various pollutants and aerosols found in the atmosphere. Polar projections allow the north and south polar regions to be central to exploration, providing hands-on visualization of the important climatic roles of these regions and highlighting changes they are undergoing. Fluid Earth is designed to be scalable so that additional data layers may be added in the future.  

Individuals and groups interested in using Fluid Earth are invited to direct their web browsers to https://fluid-earth.byrd.osu.edu. A kiosk mode within Fluid Earth, available at https://fluid-earth.byrd.osu.edu/#kmode=true, allows museums, nature centers, parks, and children's museums to feature content on a video display or touch screen without extensive IT support. 

A video tutorial of Fluid Earth's features may be viewed at ​​https://vimeo.com/579263200, and a summary of findings from deployments in middle school classrooms may be read in Cervenec et al. (2022) at https://doi-org.proxy.lib.ohio-state.edu/10.1080/10899995.2022.2038963.  

Professionals interested in reviewing or using the code underpinning Fluid Earth are invited to visit the project's code repository at https://github.com/byrd-polar/fluid-earth. An overview of the code's structure and development may be read at https://www.gislounge.com/fluid-earth-open-source-visualization-weather-climate-data/.

The project team continues to add data layers and work on initiatives to make maps and other digital geospatial data accessible to users who are blind or have limited vision.
